title: My ex lien sold a motorcycle that was being financed in my name. Can this be included in a bankruptcy?
question: My ex lien sold a motorcycle that was being financed in my name. He never made one payment and instead traded the vehicle for a debt he had incurred with said individual who now has a lien hold on the bike. He also put me over $30,000 in debt when he would steal my credit cards without my knowledge. I reluctantly decided to file bankruptcy. I still owe on the motorcycle as only 1 payment was ever made. It is actually in repossession status right now. What will happen with the bike once I file bankruptcy? Will it be added into my debts or am I still liable for the remaining $13,000?
answers: Include the bike in your bankruptcy paperwork and surrender your interest in it. Assuming you qualify for chapter 7 bankruptcy and you receive discharge order, most of your debts will be wiped out including the remaining balance on the bike. Speak with a qualified bankruptcy attorney as soon as possible.

List the motorcycle in your schedules as an item you are going to surrender. You can explain to the lender where the vehicle is. The debt will be included in your discharge order.
You should meet with a Bankruptcy Attorney in your area to make sure everything is correct on your papers and you have completed everything you need to do to obtain the discharge order and then you will be off to your Fresh Start.
May want to take a look at your requirements for a significant other so you don't end up in another financial mess because of someone else.

List the motorcycle in your schedules as an item you are going to surrender. You can explain to the lender where the vehicle is. The debt will be included in your discharge order.
You should meet with a Bankruptcy Attorney in your area to make sure everything is correct on your papers and you have completed everything you need to do to obtain the discharge order and then you will be off to your Fresh Start.

If you successfully file Chapter 7 bankruptcy, all your dischargeable debts will be discharged - including the loan on the bike.
